CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1 on account of the quashing of the judgment;Violation of P1-1 in respect of the same fact;Not necessary to examine the complaint about the length of the civil proceedings;Not necessary to examine the complaint about the alleged lack of domestic remedies in respect of the length complaint
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant took out insurance for his DATE cottage . In DATE the cottage burnt down . The insurer , a private company ( hereinafter referred as “ the company ” ) , paid only a part of the amount claimed by the applicant . The applicant brought an action against the company claiming the rest . On DATE ORG ordered the company to pay the applicant MONEY ( RUR ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , upon the applicant 's request , ORG ordered the seizure of the company 's account in a private bank “ LOC . As follows from the extract of that account , provided by the “ PERSON ” , on DATE the company had ORG CARDINAL on it . There is no indication , however , that the money on that account has ever been seized .
CARDINAL . The judgment of ORG was upheld by ORG on DATE . Following that , ORG issued an execution order against the company . On DATE the execution order was sent to the bailiff .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bailiff initiated the enforcement proceedings . On DATE the bailiff requested from ORG information about the accounts and assets of the company . ORG informed the bailiff that by DATE the company had declared RUR CARDINAL in cash and ORG on accounts in CARDINAL private banks . According to ORG , in DATE fiscal report the company had also declared RUR CARDINAL in capital assets , RUR CARDINAL in intangible assets , and RUR CARDINAL in receivable accounts .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff visited the headquarters of the company indicated in the company 's official documents , but no property belonging to the company was found at that address . On DATE the bailiff discontinued the enforcement proceedings on the ground that the defendant had no assets to seize .

CARDINAL . DATE the applicant brought an action against the bailiff . He claimed that the bailiff had failed to take appropriate steps to find and seize the company 's property . On DATE ORG ruled in the applicant 's favour . The court found , in particular , that the bailiff had failed to withdraw the debt from the defendant 's account in “ LOC . The court also found that the bailiff had breached a number of procedural rules , in particular , as it had not informed the applicant about the initiation of the enforcement proceedings . The court ordered the enforcement of the judgment in the applicant 's favour .

CARDINAL . A new bailiff was appointed to deal with the applicant 's case . However , he found no money on CARDINAL of the defendant 's accounts , including the CARDINAL in “ LOC ” . On DATE the enforcement proceedings were discontinued .

CARDINAL . The applicant challenged the discontinuation of the proceedings in court . On CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed the bailiff 's decision and ordered the re - opening of the enforcement proceedings . The court found , in particular , that the bailiff had failed to establish the real whereabouts of the company and its property . On DATE ORG dismissed ORG appeal against that decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiff again discontinued the enforcement proceedings in view of the absence of assets belonging to the defendant . The applicant did not appeal against this decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought an action for damages against ORG , which is responsible for ORG . On DATE the GPE ORG recognised the liability of ORG for the non - execution of the judgment of DATE as upheld on DATE . The court granted the applicant damages in the amount of RUR CARDINAL , i.e. the sum which he had initially claimed from the company . This judgment was not appealed against and became final on DATE . It was transmitted to the bailiffs for enforcement .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG lodged with ORG an extraordinary appeal against the judgment of DATE . The ORG also suspended the enforcement proceedings . On DATE the Presidium of ORG dismissed the appeal , upholding the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy Prosecutor General lodged with ORG of GPE a new extraordinary appeal against the judgment of DATE . He alleged , inter alia , that the GPE ORG should have imposed responsibility for the alleged non - execution on the ORG , not ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE granted the prosecutor 's appeal and quashed the judgment of DATE , primarily on the ground that the first instance court had not established a causal link between the alleged negligence of the bailiffs and the damages allegedly incurred by the applicant . The case was remitted to the GPE ORG for a fresh examination .

CARDINAL . The applicant indicated that following the quashing of the judgment of DATE by ORG the hearings were repeatedly adjourned , mainly due to the defendant 's failure to appear before the court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's claim . The court found no liability of ORG for the non - execution of the judgment . On DATE ORG , acting as a court of appeal , quashed the judgment of DATE , remitting the case to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Presnenskiy District Court again refused the applicant 's claim . It stated that the applicant was not deprived of his property as a result of the actions of ORG . Although the court acknowledged that ORG actions prevented the applicant from recovering his money , it declared that the actions of ORG “ only hindered compensation for damage ” , but “ did not cause damage ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the judgment . On DATE the ORG rejected the appeal as the applicant had not paid court fees . The applicant appealed against the decision , claiming that he was exempted from paying the fees . On DATE ORG upheld the decision of DATE . However , on DATE the ORG of ORG overruled that decision , stating that the applicant should have been exempted from paying the fees .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the applicant 's appeal . It upheld the judgment of LOC of DATE . ORG reiterated that as a result of the bailiff 's actions the applicant had not been deprived of his possession and the bailiff 's actions were only a hindrance to a full compensation for damages caused by the insurance company .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW provides that any acts or failure to act by ORG authorities may be appealed against to a court . Pursuant to the PERSON “ On enforcement proceedings ” of DATE , any decision of the bailiff can be challenged in court within DATE from the moment when the concerned person learned about this decision ( LAW ) . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of this law stipulate that the damage caused by the bailiffs should be compensated under general rules of civil responsibility .
CARDINAL . For relevant details concerning the supervisory review proceedings see the ORG v. GPE judgment ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE , § § CARDINAL ) .
